body: ideally we could put huge (> 1 TB) datasets into grid
This would probably start to fail in training because it will try to load the entire set into memory

Shouldn't it be fairly straightforward to split into batches and train on each batch in sequence?  Thinking client identifies the batch, sends a piece of each batch to the workers, training happens for a full pass, then the client sends an interrupt signal followed by the next batch.
i can look into this if no one else has started
nvm I think @robert-wagner is looking into it
Pytorch has begun! #15
Don't merge yet -- ongoing discussion in slack #grid channel
I implemented this for blockchain as well as pysyft so I can probably do it pretty quick.
I'll do this

I'm not sure there is a way to do this with pubsub, or with IPFS at all.  Someone please correct me if I am wrong.

With pubsub, I don't know if there is a way to persist the messages, something like a dead letter exchange is needed.

With IPFS, I can't think of a way to store a job in ipfs in such a way that a worker coming online late would know where to look to find work.

This is also in line with the designs that have been created.  Theoretically, a user should always have the ability to pause or stop the training of a model for whatever reason.

Thanks for doing this @bendecoste - let me know if you need any assistance.
This is broken for a minute. DO NOT MERGE YET
Fixed. Merge whenever
Hold up on merging this.  I need to actually test it with another person.
Tested this with justin and it looks good
succeeded by #41
How are we looking on this?
I think @bendecoste  is going to do a small change. He was planning to fix the method signature to use the values in the dictionary.
Seems like something [Adapters](https://github.com/OpenMined/Adapters) should handle?  If not in the near-term, somewhere down the line.

I think `Client.fit` should return everything you need.  I think we want it to return a message of type `transact` with the address of the best model at `model_addr`, so then all you'd need to do is call `best_model, _ = Client.receive_model(model_addr)` to receive the model you want, and then you'd use it like any other Keras model.

We should also eventually have a log of all the different models from training, so that if the user prefers a different model from the training process, they can extract the IPFS address from a log and call `receive_model` on it, e.g. if they suspect it to perform better for some reason.

@jvmancuso agreed - the next step for this project is probably just to require that the input data be in a matrix format (which the adapters spec is responsible for transforming it into). This would then let the Grid Tree specify arbitrary required numbers of input dimensions which should be quite flexible for many use cases.
(except for recurrent ones and RL ones)
